abstract.p: Objectives. To assess stability of a new-design titanium implant (Cochlear Baha BAI300) in bone-anchored hearing aid (Baha) recipients over time.
Study Design and Setting. Prospective case series with planned data collection at a tertiary care institution. Twelve patients who underwent Baha surgery over 12 months were analyzed.

Subjects. All patients (3 children, age range 6-10 years, mean 7.7 years, median 7.3 years; 9 adults, age range 34-73 years, mean 52.8 years, median 48 years) underwent the 1-stage procedure following the standard Brånemark technique. In all procedures, the single-skin incision was applied.

Methods. The stability of the implant was measured with implant stability quotient (ISQ) measurement tests. All patients were tested at surgery and every week after for 1 year. Wound-healing time, degree of soft tissue reactions around the abutment, and need for revision surgery were examined. Two-tailed Student t test and χ2 for all comparisons were calculated; P < .05 values were considered significant.

Results. The new implant showed a steep increase of ISQ values over the first 2 weeks and reached stable ISQ values 3 weeks after surgery. Complete skin healing time was obtained in 8 days on average (range, 7-12 days; median 7.6 days). Neither implant extrusion nor skin revision surgery was observed in our patients during the first year of follow-up.
Conclusions. This new implant revealed stability and fast integration. The data from the present study suggest the new implant may be suitable for early loading protocols.

body.p: The Baha system (Cochlear Bone Anchored Solutions AB, Mölnycke, Sweden) is an effective and well-established surgical option for hearing rehabilitation. Initially described for the treatment of conductive and mixed hearing losses,1 the Baha system is now also used in cases of single-sided deafness (SSD), such as acoustic neuroma or sudden sensorineural hearing loss.2,3 The process of osseointegration to obtain stable anchoring of titanium implants in craniofacial epistheses and hearing aids is time dependent, and different surgeons have used varied time frames before loading the implant.4,5 In general, clinical studies have reported good results with a healing period (along with implant stability) of 3 months in adults and 6 months in children before connecting the hearing aid.6,7 Dense bone structures (ie, the temporal bone) seem to provide better healing and implant stability over time.8 Conversely, failure to prolonged implant osseointegration is more frequently observed in the irradiated bone, in elderly subjects with reduced healing ability, and in the pediatric ages.9-14 On the other hand, there is a need to improve clinical outcome, simplify clinical procedures, and load the implant earlier in some situations.

Different studies on earlier loading revealed no increased extrusion rate for patients with implants loaded 6 weeks postoperatively compared with those loaded 3 months postoperatively.4,9 Early loading times and 1-stage procedures have been proposed recently to shorten and simplify the treatment for a bone conduction hearing solution in selected cases and children.4,15,16 In dental surgery, even in the presence of strong applied forces, implant loading ranges from immediate to 6 months,4 and early loading protocols are clinical routine, with follow-up studies showing similarly good results as 2-stage protocols.17,18 One possible explanation is probably the development of new implant surfaces.19 Several studies revealed a stronger and faster osseointegration to titanium in implants with moderately rough surfaces.19-24 In addition, craniofacial implants with rough and TiO2-blasted surface are related to a stronger bone tissue response with direct formation of osteoid and bone by osteoblasts onto implant surfaces,20-22,24,25 thus showing faster integration and implant stability quotient (ISQ) in an animal model.24,25

In this light, we evaluated a newly designed craniofacial implant applied to Baha surgery: the Cochlear Baha BIA300 implant with TiO2-blasted (TiO2-blast; Astra Tech, Mölndal, Sweden) abutment (Cochlear Bone Anchored Solutions AB). We assessed insertion torque, ISQ measures, and complications that occurred in bone anchored-hearing recipients with regard to wound healing after single-stage with single-incision Baha (3SB) surgery.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This was a prospective case series with planned data collection study at a tertiary care otologic institution, performed from July 28, 2010, to September 3, 2011. The institutional review board (IRB) and the Internal Ethics Committee (IEC-VI) from the first author’s institution approved the study protocol. The IRB and the IEC-VI approved the study to be performed for patients enrolled in 1 year only. Written informed consent was obtained from each patient before admission (from parents or caregiver in the case of children).

Twenty-one patients were evaluated in our clinic and considered appropriate candidates for 3SB surgery during the IRB-approved time frame. Of these, 12 agreed to participate in this study, 1 child for a bilateral simultaneous procedure (13 ears total), and were scheduled for the 3SB procedure. Six subjects were male and 6 female, and all patients (3 children, age range 6-10 years, mean 7.7 years, median 7.3 years; 9 adults, age range 34-73 years, mean 52.8 years, median 48 years) underwent the 3SB procedure.

All cases were performed under local anesthesia except in children (3 patients, 4 ears). All patients were operated on by the same attending surgeon (RDE). In all patients, the single-stage, single-incision procedure was applied under local anesthesia, except in children (3 patients, 4 ears).

The single-incision technique, previously described in the literature,10,26-28 was applied in all cases. The cutaneous linear incision of approximately 3.5 cm was performed with a #15 blade down to the periosteum. After elevating the 2 soft tissue flaps, the periosteum was gently elevated with a Freer elevator, and the drilling and abutment placement procedures were performed as recommended by the manufacturer28 in all patients. The only difference was the torque applied: 40 to 50 Nm in adults, 30 to 40 Ncm in children.

All patients received 1 implant only: no “sleeper” abutment was placed. All subjects were implanted with the Cochlear BIA300 implant with abutment (mod. 92126—3 mm length in children; mod. 92127—4 mm length in adults). Subsequently, subcutaneous tissue reduction was performed as recommended.26,28 All drilling and abutment placement procedures and the subsequent soft tissue work were performed under magnification using ×2.5 surgical loupes. Upon completion of surgery, the first ISQ measures were obtained. A Smartpeg #55 (Osstell Corp, Göteborg, Sweden) was applied on the internal screw of the abutment with a torque of 5 to 10 Ncm, and ISQ measures were obtained along the anteroposterior (AP) and superoinferior (SI) axes. Data were added to each patient’s datasheet created right after surgery. The same postoperative care dressing was performed in all cases, as previously described.26-28 In all patients, a pressure head dressing was applied overnight to prevent hematoma.

On postoperative day 1, all patients were checked before discharge. The healing cap and antibiotic gauze were removed 1 week postoperatively, at the first outpatient visit. Patients were reevaluated in the clinic every week postoperatively for the first 3 months, then every month for 9 months. Implant ISQ measures were performed during every visit, and ISQ values were added to each patient’s datasheet for further analysis. The same surgeon at every follow-up examination, with the use of ×2.5 magnification surgical loupes, evaluated skin interface at the implantation site. Soft tissue reactions around the abutment were assessed and classified according to Holgers et al29 (Table 1). Subjects of the present study were loaded 3 weeks after surgery. Two-tailed Student t test and χ2 for all comparisons were calculated; P < .05 values were considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Twelve patients were implanted between July 2010 and September 2011. Among these patients, 1 child received a bilateral simultaneous implant for a total of 13 implants. Etiology of hearing loss is reported in Table 2. The most common reason for implantation was SSD (5 patients). Among these 5, one was a 34-year-old woman affected by type II neurofibromatosis (NF-II). She received the implant on the dead-ear side where radiation therapy was first attempted, followed by acoustic neuroma (AN) surgery, 1 year later. Another patient with SSD had an AN removal. The remaining 3 SSD ears were following unilateral sudden idiopathic profound hearing loss. Three patients had undergone a canal wall-down procedure with no ossicular chain reconstruction. Among patients with congenital aural atresia (n = 2), 1 child presented with unilateral hemifacial hyposomia and cleft palate (repaired at 16 months). In 1 of these patients, a bilateral Baha simultaneous procedure was performed.

sec.p: Two patients had otosclerosis with severe conductive hearing loss due to failed surgical attempt on the ossicular chain in 1 case, whereas a congenital conductive hearing loss was present in the other.

In all 3 children (4 ears) and 1 adult, dura was encountered at final drilling, but this did not result in violation of the dural tissue in all cases, even after standard countersink application and drilling. Children received the 3-mm implant, whereas the adult received a 4-mm implant. Surgery and postoperative care proceeded for these patients as it did for all uncomplicated patients, with an uneventful recovery. In all adults with the BAI300 implant, final application torque was 50 Ncm, whereas it was 40 Ncm in children, with an uneventful postoperative period.

sec.title: Implant Stability
sec.p: All implants were subjected to ISQ measurements using specially designed Smartpegs (Integration Diagnostics AB, Gamlestadvagen, Sweden) and an Osstell Mentor instrument (Osstell AB, Goteborg, Sweden). Measurements were made along the AP axis and along the posteroinferior (PI) axis, in a perpendicular fashion, with the fulcrum centered at the implant site. Measures were plotted in each patient’s datasheet. The follow-up time frame ranged from 12 to 14 months (median 12.2 months). During follow-up, a total of 728 observations (and ISQ measurements) were made in all patients.

Observations were tallied on the basis of abutments implanted, so that patients with 2 implants counted as double at each follow-up visit. Implant stability quotient analysis per visit revealed a steep increase in ISQ values during the first 2 weeks after implantation, reaching a plateau at the third postoperative week (Figure 1). No decrease in ISQ values was observed during the initial healing period. After 3 weeks, stability values continued to be stable over the 14-month time of observation. No significant difference in ISQ was observed between children and adults 3 weeks after implantation. Evaluation of ISQ stability after loading the sound processor and fitting revealed no reduction in ISQ values in all loaded implants. The longitudinal analysis of ISQ values revealed minimal within-patient difference over time, and repeated statistics measures yielded no significant stability decrease through the 1-year follow-up (P = .5). Analyses between the preloading and the postloading time frames revealed no significant difference (P = .110 for all comparisons).

caption.p: Mean implant stability quotient (ISQ) values are reported over time. A steep increase in ISQ values was obtained during the first 2 weeks after implantation, reaching a plateau at the third week. No significant ISQ changes were observed over the 1-year follow-up.

sec.title: Soft Tissue Reaction
sec.p: No skin, scar, or soft tissue proliferation requiring surgical removal was observed in our series. No patient required removal of the abutment during the observation period of this study. No skin flap necrosis requiring revision was encountered. Wound healing was obtained within 8 days in all cases, but sutures were removed 14 days after surgery to obtain the stable tensile strength of the wound. No irritation (ie, Holgers grade 0) was observed in 98.5% of patients (Table 1), whereas a grade 1 Holgers reaction (ie, slight redness of skin around the implant) was encountered in 1.1% of cases. In 3 observations, only a grade 2 local reaction (red and slightly moist tissue) was observed, which promptly resolved after 7 days of local treatment. All local reactions occurred after 6 months postoperatively.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The new BAI300 implant has been designed to enhance stability both at implantation and over time. It features a wider implant diameter (4.5 mm vs 3.75 mm of the previous implant) with smaller threads in the outermost segment of the intraosseus-implanted portion. In addition, the moderately rough TiO2-blasted surface is claimed to gain faster osseointegration because of both the roughness of the material and the intrinsic nature of the TiO2. New implant design, dimensions, and characteristics have been proven to follow claimed improvements in preclinical experimental studies and in clinical investigation in humans.24,25,30

In the present study, we observed high ISQ values with the BAI300 at the time of implantation. These data compare well with previous observations in the literature,24,25,30 and this may be due to the wider implant diameter.24,25,30,31 However, we did not observe any decrease in stability measures during the first days after implantation, and this may be associated with the different insertion torque forces applied (40-50 Ncm) in our series. Probably, the higher torques allowed by this new implant design prevailed over the initial bone-remodeling process consisting of bone relaxation and resorption triggered by insertion trauma.30

Despite the small sample size, we did not observe a significant difference in ISQ values between children and adults 3 weeks after surgery. The high bone remodeling in children may have played a role, but further larger sample investigation is needed.

As bone healing proceeded, ISQ values reached the plateau allowed by the intrinsic features of the bone-implant interface. The fast osseointegration activated by the rough surface of the inner portion of the implant enhanced by the TiO2-blasted composition, the additional torque, and the different thread design may have played a role. These improvements during the early healing phase have been previously reported in dental22,30 and Baha literature31 and may explain the rapid and linear increase of ISQ values in our series. Dental implants commercially available feature modified surfaces as a requirement for successful use in early loading procedures.18

The level of osseointegration we observed 3 weeks after implantation was stable over time and similar to our previous clinical observation (unpublished data) and considered adequate to support the bone-anchored sound processor. This allowed us to load all implants as early as 3 weeks after surgery, with no deterioration in implant stability observed during the following 1-year follow-up (Figure 1). This result is consistent with favorable outcomes as observed elsewhere in the literature,24,25,30 and thus early loading protocols in Baha surgery may be considered an option that deserves further larger investigations.

No implant loss was encountered among our patients, even if the series was limited, but this compares positively with similar implant survival rates reported.30 Larger series with early loading protocols may add additional evidence support in the future, and further investigations addressing this issue might reduce the in limbo time frame that patients experience between surgery and sound processor loading.

Baha soft tissue complications are generally mild to moderate, and skin reactions around the implant site are variable.7-9,26,30 Meticulous soft tissue handling during surgery and after implantation is the key to achieve both reduced skin reaction rate and low Holgers index response,9,30 and improved implant design seems to enhance this favorable outcome.30 The low skin reaction rates (Table 2) we observed with the BAI300 implant are consistent with observations of Dun et al.30 Most likely, the cup-shaped abutment, along with the lower angle at the skin-implant interface, increases the peri-implant skin stability, resulting in a more favorable soft tissue outcome, but the impact of implant design on skin reactions should be issue of additional study.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The new BAI300 implant provided high stability and fast integration as measured by ISQ at the time of surgery and after 1 year of observation. No decrease in stability was observed after sound processor loading at 3 weeks after surgery and during the 1-year follow-up, thus suggesting early loading procedures for Baha. Additional larger studies with long-term follow-up are advisable to confirm these data.
